docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of the presidential debate last night in St. Louis between President Bush and Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator was Charles Gibson of ABC News. The questioners were potential voters who said they were undecided. MR. GIBSON -- Good evening. From the Field House at Washington University in St. Louis, I'm Charles Gibson of ABC News and ''Good Morning America.'' I welcome you to the second of the 2004 presidential debates between President George W. Bush, the Republican nominee, and Senator John Kerry, the Democratic nominee. The debates are sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

headline.main: THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: The 2nd Presidential Debate; The Presidential Candidates' 2nd Debate: 'These Are the Differences'

docs.abstract: Transcript of second, 'town hall'-style debate between Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Following is a transcript of the presidential debate last night in St. Louis between President Bush and Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator was Charles Gibson of ABC News. The questioners were...

docs.lead_paragraph: In an escalation of their tactics, striking casino service workers blocked the main access road to Atlantic City for about 20 minutes Friday evening just as the busy Columbus Day weekend traffic began flooding into town. About 100 strikers in red T-shirts sat down in a circle at Atlantic and Missouri Avenues, where the Atlantic City Expressway spills arriving visitors into the narrow city streets. The Atlantic City police said that about 80 demonstrators were arrested and given tickets for disorderly conduct and obstructing traffic. Union officials were on hand at police headquarters to pay the tickets.

headline.main: 80 Casino Strikers Are Arrested for Blocking Road Into Atlantic City

docs.abstract: About 100 striking casino service workers block main access road to Atlantic City for about 20 minutes just as busy Columbus Day weekend traffic begins flooding into town; police arrest about 80 demonstrators; photos (M)
docs.snippet: In an escalation of their tactics, striking casino service workers blocked the main access road to Atlantic City for about 20 minutes.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: HOTEL EMPLOYEES AND RESTAURANT EMPLOYEES INTERNATIONAL UNION

docs.lead_paragraph: As if times were not troubled enough in the airline industry, employees at US Airways, Delta and United are facing the stark realization that the security they hoped their jobs would provide is being quickly taken away. Over the last week, US Airways and Delta employees have learned that they will not have company-paid health care benefits when they retire. Those airlines are also reducing vacation and sick time, and eliminating or curbing contributions to their pension plans. United has said it may terminate its pension plans as it tries to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

headline.main: Airline Workers See Their Security Quickly Vanish

docs.abstract: Security that employees at US Airways, Delta and United once counted on is being eroded under new economics of airline industry, which may be applied to other airlines as well; cuts in compensation, pensions and retirees' health-care benefits come as psychological blow, but some employees see them as delayed reaction to financial problems that have swept industry since 2000; some experts say jobs like reservations and airline ticket-counter agents can no longer be looked upon as providing careers, particularly as technology evolves to make such positions less necessary; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Employees at US Airways, Delta and United are facing the stark realization that the security they hoped their jobs would provide is being taken away.

docs.lead_paragraph: From the beginning of the year, the White House has charted new ground with the sweep of its negative campaigning, starting with an $80 million wave of attack advertisements directed at Senator John Kerry that began the moment he effectively won his party's nomination last spring. But the scathing indictment that Mr. Bush offered of Mr. Kerry over the past two days -- on the eve of the second presidential debate and with polls showing the race tightening -- took these attacks to a blistering new level. In the process, several analysts say, Mr. Bush pushed the limits of subjective interpretation and offered exaggerated or what some Democrats said were distorted accounts of Mr. Kerry's positions on health care, tax cuts, the Iraq war and foreign policy.

headline.main: In His New Attacks, Bush Pushes Limit on the Facts

docs.abstract: White House has charted new ground from beginning of year with sweep of its negative campaigning, starting with $80 million wave of attack ads directed at Sen John Kerry that began moment he effectively won his party's nomination; Bush's scathing indictment of Kerry over past two days takes these attacks to blistering new level; several analysts see Bush pushing limits of subjective interpretation and offering exaggerated or what some Democrats say are distorted accounts of Kerry's positions on major issues; Bush's aides defend his statements, but other analysts, including some Republicans, say Bush is repeatedly taking phrases and sentences out of context, or cherry-picking votes, to provide unfavorable case against Kerry; examples cited (M)
docs.snippet: Several analysts say that President Bush has pushed the limits of subjective interpretation and offered exaggerated or imprecise accounts of John Kerry's policy positions.

byline.original: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and RICHARD W. STEVENSON

docs.lead_paragraph: They are often on stage with President Bush when he talks about the economy on the campaign trail: entrepreneurs whose business has turned up. There was George Puentes in Beaverton, Ore., whose tortilla-making company has hired more than 30 workers this year; Jim Bell in Derry, N.H., whose electronics company added 17 employees, and others like them in Wisconsin and Missouri and Pennsylvania. Their stories are the president's reply to those who cast him as a tool of his wealthy benefactors and a captive of corporate interests. He is at heart a small-business man, he suggests, bent on helping risk-takers seize the American dream and build prosperity, job by job.

headline.main: President Has Aggressively Pursued 'Pro-Growth' Ideas Nurtured in the Texas Oil Fields

docs.abstract: Fourth article in series The Bush Record examines Pres Bush's economic policy; he is vigorously defending his tax cuts and his broader agenda of deregulation, more trade and limits on lawsuits; his fortunes on these issues will hinge more on economy's performance than on his effort to position himself as candidate of the little guy, or on Democratic claims that he has done little but make rich richer and business better for likes of some corrupt corporations; his positions are often criticized from both ends of ideological spectrum as too politically opportunistic to be coherent philosophy; he seems to have created new variant of conservative orthodoxy, emphasizing choice and responsibility while acknowledging more substantial role for government than free-market purists would like; graphs (L)
docs.snippet: The economy has been growing since late in 2001, robustly at times, but despite three substantial tax-cut packages job creation has been modest at best.

docs.lead_paragraph: Odessa, the West Texas town where ''Friday Night Lights'' is set, is the kind of place where football is pronounced FUH-paw and where it is routinely described as a religion. With all due respect to God, it may be even more than that. The impression of Odessa that emerges from Peter Berg's new film, and from the scrupulously reported 1990 book by H. G. Bissinger on which it is based, is of a self-contained world in which high school football, played in a stadium bigger than ones at many colleges, is more important than church, state, sex, money or anything else. The sport's power is sacred and secular: it holds the social order together and gives individual lives a sense of meaning and high purpose. Early in the movie the teenage boys who play for Permian High School are told that their duty is ''to protect this town'' -- a job description that somehow doesn't seem metaphorical. Odessa during football season resembles a besieged garrison, and these kids are its soldiers. This is a lot to ask of such young men, and sometimes the burden of expectation sits heavily on their pumped-up shoulders.

headline.main: Glory Days on the Gridiron: Young Manhood, Texas Style

docs.abstract: A O Scott reviews movie Friday Night Lights, directed by Peter Berg and starring Billy Bob Thornton and Derek Luke; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Peter Berg directs this Texas high school football extravaganza in a tough, gritty style that gives it an unusually fine and vivid sense of place.

docs.lead_paragraph: Civil liberties lawyers sued the Bloomberg administration in federal court yesterday, charging that the Police Department had subjected protesters during the Republican National Convention to wrongful arrest, improper fingerprinting and lengthy, harrowing detention. Two complaints, filed in Manhattan, describe marchers suddenly swept into orange nets, languishing on buses in tight handcuffs without medical attention, and one woman, panicked, in convulsions after being corralled into a mass arrest as she walked to work.

headline.main: Lawyers' Group Sues City Over Arrests of Protesters

docs.abstract: New York Civil Liberties Union sues Bloomberg administration on behalf of several plaintiffs, charging that Police Dept subjected protesters during Republican National Convention to wrongful arrest, improper fingerprinting and lengthy, harrowing detention; suits seek unspecified damages but ask court to declare arrest and detention tactics illegal to prevent city from using them again; city officials call accusations false (M)
docs.snippet: Civil liberties lawyers charged that the Police Department had subjected protesters during the Republican National Convention to wrongful arrest.
